forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Ok I have gotten pretty far on my own. I got it all figured out (I think) except that I need the proper line to place in the boot.ini folder. I currently get the hal.dll error. Here is the way it looks now. This is not the whole file obviously. > >
> > ``` > multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(0)partition(1)\i386\winnt.exe="Microsoft Windows XP Professional install" /fastdetect > ``` > >
>
Well, that line - no offence intended ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif)- means that your "pretty far" and "all" is between 0 (zero) and 0.42% of the actual knowledge needed. ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif) You cannot (meaning that you CANNOT) run WINNT.EXE (which is a DOS 16-bit program) without DOS, and DEFINITELY NOT by putting it in a BOOT.INI line. IF your target drive is to be formatted as FAT16 or FAT32, you can load DOS, and from it run WINNT.EXE. Otherwise you need to either: * load a PE (Pre-installation Environment) of some kind (LiveXP suggested) and run from it WINNT32.EXE, or this: (EASIEST) or * you can use a bootmanager, like grub4dos or Syslinux or the like to run the actual install loader (SETUPLDR.BIN) from another partition (more "advanced")
Or, even more "advanced", you can use one of the above bootmanagers in conjunction with a suitable filedisk/ramdisk drivers, such as Firadisk or WinVblock to load a .iso or .img of the actual install source. The NTLDR (and conversely BOOT.INI) ONLY can boot: * an ARCPATH pointing to a DIRECTORY (containing an ALREADY installed NT), example: > multi(0)disk(0)rdisk(0)partition(1)\\windows="Microsoft Windows XP Professional" * a binary file representing a volume bootsector or code that "works the same", examples: > C:\\bootsect.dos="MS-DOS" or > C:\\grldr="grub4dos"
![:thumbsup:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/thumbsup.gif) Wonko

While that is a good way to generate business, it's not my cup of tea. I would like to give him a solution for the next time.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
The XP install deletes it's files when run on writable media.  

You need to read the "historical" thread of the "Install Windows from USB" forum, here:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...l-from-usb-key/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/61384-how-to-bootinstall-from-usb-key/ "External link")  
AND this:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...omusb-with-gui/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/120444-how-to-install-windows-from-usb-winsetupfromusb-with-gui/ "External link")  
AND this:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...ll-xp-from-usb/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/111406-how-to-install-xp-from-usb/ "External link")  
and extract from them the parts that do apply to HD initiated install (no matter if internally connected or USB connected).  

Or if you still don't want to use the PE method, you can use this:  
[http://www.msfn.org/...aded-iso-image/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/137714-install-xp-from-a-ram-loaded-iso-image/ "External link")
